questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because he has had multiple falls and multiple episodes of dizziness over the past 6 weeks. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He drinks one pint of rum daily. He works as a foreman in a factory that produces industrial solvents. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a wide-based gait. The patient is unable to stand with his feet together without support. There is a coarse tremor of the hands when he is asked to grab a pen. Muscle strength and tone are normal in all extremities. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is intact bilaterally. Rapid alternating movements of the hands is impaired. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency due to alcohol use disorder is a risk factor for Korsakoff syndrome, but this condition does not cause ataxia or dizziness. Instead, patients characteristically have anterograde and retrograde amnesia (as a result of damage to the memory circuits) and confabulate to fill in details of past events.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with an alcohol use disorder are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency, which may result in subacute combined degeneration (SCD). SCD may result in multiple falls as a result of sensory ataxia and/or lower limb weakness. However, patients would be able to perform a Romberg test, unlike this patient. To maintain balance, at least 2 of the 3 following sensory inputs are necessary: vision, proprioception, and vestibular function. By taking away vision input upon closing the eyes during a Romberg test, a patient with defective proprioception (as in SCD) loses balance and the test is positive. Also, this patient has normal muscle strength as well as intact vibration and joint position sense in the lower limbs, which would be absent in SCD.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the patient's occupational history and his alcohol use disorder are risk factors for methanol poisoning, it is typically an acute condition that presents with CNS depression, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and/or abdominal pain.

D) CORRECT:

Dysdiadochokinesia, intention tremors, vertigo, and a wide-based gait indicate cerebellar ataxia. Degeneration of the superior cerebellar vermis is the most common cause of subacute or chronic ataxia in patients with excessive alcohol use. Cerebellar degeneration in this patient group occurs due to the direct toxic effects of alcohol or as a result of thiamine deficiency.

Patients with severe thiamine deficiency may also develop Wernicke encephalopathy as a result of neuronal injury in the thalamic nuclei, mamillary bodies, periaqueductal gray matter, and/or floor of the fourth ventricle. If Wernicke encephalopathy is not recognized and treated, patients will develop an irreversible Korsakoff syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency due to alcohol use disorder is a risk factor for Wernicke encephalopathy, which may present with ataxia. However, patients with Wernicke encephalopathy would also have other features such as delirium and/or evidence of ocular muscle weakness (e.g., nystagmus). Additionally, dizziness would not be an expected symptom.
questions.hint: What is the most common cause of ataxia in patients with alcohol use disorder?

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for 2 months. He has been falling to his left side when he walks more than a few feet. His speech has also changed in the past few months, and he now pauses between each syllable. He has never had similar symptoms before. He has hypertension and cirrhosis as a result of alcohol-associated liver disease. He does not smoke, and he no longer drinks alcohol. His current medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide daily. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows discrete scleral icterus and jaundice. Ascites and gynecomastia are present. Neurological examination shows nystagmus with fast beats toward the left. He has dysmetria and tremor when performing left-sided finger-nose testing, and dysdiadochokinesia with rapid alternating movements. He has a wide-based gait and a pronator drift of the left arm. He has full range of motion in his arms and legs without rigidity. He has full muscle strength, and sensation to light touch is intact. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-related cerebellar degeneration can manifest with gait ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus. However, individuals with this condition typically have symptoms of bilateral cerebellar dysfunction, and this patient's symptoms appear to be limited to the left side. Additionally, patients with alcohol-related cerebellar degeneration most commonly have gaze-evoked nystagmus.

B) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B12 deficiency may manifest with gait ataxia, individuals with this condition typically present with spinal ataxia due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and subsequently impaired proprioception. This patient's abnormalities in speech and eye movement indicate a different type of ataxia. Additionally, neurological symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency are usually bilateral and include sensory disturbances.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperammonemia is a diagnostic feature of hepatic encephalopathy, which is characterized by an altered mental state, impaired cognition, a flapping tremor, and slurred speech. The condition is caused by severe liver disease, such as cirrhosis. Although this patient has an increased risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, he presents with dysdiadochokinesia, ataxia, and nystagmus, which are not features of the condition. Furthermore, his normal mental state and intention tremor suggest that another cause is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is most often due to chronic alcohol consumption, causes Wernicke encephalopathy, which manifests with gait ataxia, oculomotor dysfunction, and confusion, and severe disease may progress to coma. Because the patient has no neuropsychiatric symptoms and no longer drinks alcohol, thiamine deficiency is not the most likely cause of his condition.

E) CORRECT:

Typical symptoms caused by cerebellar tumors include gait ataxia, truncal ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and pronator drift. The symptoms manifest ipsilaterally to the lesion site in the cerebellum. Since the patient shows left-beating nystagmus, left-leaning ataxia, and left-sided pronator drift, the tumor must be located in the left part of the cerebellum.

F) INCORRECT:

Infarctions in the internal capsule manifest as lacunar strokes. Although the patient has hypertension and therefore his risk for stroke is increased, an infarction of the left posterior internal capsule would cause contralateral hemiparesis. The patient has no symptoms affecting the right side of his body and does not suffer from hemiparesis.
questions.hint: This patient would likely lose balance if he attempted to stand with his feet together, regardless of whether his eyes were open or closed (negative Romberg test).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a follow-up examination. Ten days ago, he was diagnosed with chickenpox. His parents report that over the past 2 days he has had difficulty walking straight. He has fallen multiple times and is unable to walk up the stairs without assistance. His family follows a strict vegetarian diet. He has not yet received any childhood vaccinations. His mother has a history of generalized anxiety disorder. He is at the 70th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination shows a broad-based, staggering gait. Skin examination shows scattered crusted vesicles with hypopigmented macules and healing excoriations. His speech is slow and segmented; there are noticeable pauses between syllables. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intention tremor can be seen in patients with acute cerebellar ataxia, which typically occurs in children under 6 years of age and is characterized by an acute onset of cerebellar dysfunction, often preceded by a febrile illness. The clinical manifestations depend on the structure affected within the cerebellum. Damage to the vermis of the cerebellum typically leads to a broad-based gait and gait instability, which is seen here. It can also lead to truncal ataxia, dysmetria (which can also result from damage to the cerebellar hemispheres), saccadic intrusions, and vertigo. Damage to the cerebellar hemispheres typically leads to scanning speech, which this patient has, dysdiadochokinesis, intention tremor, limb ataxia, and nystagmus. Acute cerebellar ataxia commonly affects both midline cerebellar structures and cerebellar hemispheres. Although now uncommon in the US because of widespread vaccination, VZV infection was once the most common cause of acute cerebellar ataxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Romberg test can be used to differentiate between sensory and cerebellar ataxia. A positive Romberg test, in which a patient is unable to stand upright with feet together and eyes closed but has normal balance when the eyes are open, is a possible finding in patients with sensory ataxia. This patient, however, presents with signs and symptoms of cerebellar rather than sensory ataxia. Patients with cerebellar ataxia are unsteady when eyes are open or closed, i.e., Romberg test is negative.

C) INCORRECT:

An extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign) is a possible finding in patients with upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions, which can cause gait instability. However, patients with UMN lesions typically present with hypertonia, hyperreflexia, and decreased muscle strength.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity areflexia is seen in patients with lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions, which can cause gait instability. However, patients with LMN lesions typically present with a steppage gait rather than a broad-based gait. In addition, hypotonia and decreased muscle strength would also be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Conjugate horizontal gaze palsy is seen in patients with internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which is commonly caused by multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient, however, has signs of cerebellar dysfunction, which typically manifests with horizontal nystagmus rather than gaze palsy. In addition, the onset of MS is typically between 20–40 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient shows signs of acute cerebellar ataxia (e.g., abnormal, broad-based gait, imbalance, scanning speech), a rare neurological complication of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection that is typically self-limiting.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, she underwent right upper lobectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy for locally advanced adenocarcinoma of the lung. Since her last office visit, her speech has changed. She now makes awkward pauses in her sentences and breaks down words into separate syllables. On physical examination, her movements are uncoordinated and she leans to the right side when standing up. A CT scan of the brain shows a well-circumscribed tumor in her right cerebellar hemisphere. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Upbeat nystagmus is a form of involuntary, rhythmic eye movement. It is associated with lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, one of the medial structures of the cerebellum. Other manifestations of medial cerebellum injury include head bobbing, wide-based gait, and inability to stand or sit upright. A lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere most commonly manifests with horizontal nystagmus, not upbeat nystagmus.

B) CORRECT:

The finger-to-nose test assesses for appendicular coordination; an abnormal result (i.e., the patient overshoots the target or misses the tip of their nose) indicates dysmetria. Dysmetria is one of several manifestations of limb ataxia due to cerebellar hemisphere injury. Other manifestations include dysarthria (which this patient has), dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, and intention tremor. Typically, the lesions affect the ipsilateral side, which explains why this patient leans toward the right side upon standing.

C) INCORRECT:

Truncal ataxia manifests with a wide-based gait and difficulty sitting upright due to weakness and discoordination of truncal muscles. Truncal ataxia is associated with lesions in the medial cerebellum (e.g., vermis, flocculonodular lobe, and corresponding deep nuclei). This patient's limb ataxia and right hemisphere metastasis are evidence of a lateral lesion, which would not manifest with truncal ataxia.

D) INCORRECT:

Resting tremors manifest when the affected body part is relaxed and resolve with voluntary movement. This condition is commonly associated with Parkinson disease, which is caused by dysfunction of the substantia nigra in the basal ganglia. Cerebellar hemisphere lesions are associated with intention tremors (worsen with voluntary movements), not resting tremors.

E) INCORRECT:

The Romberg test assesses sensory ataxia. A positive test (patients lose balance while standing upright with their eyes closed) is associated with damage to the dorsal columns of the spine. It is not associated with damage to the lateral cerebellar hemisphere.
questions.hint: The medial cerebellum primarily manages the coordination of central structures. The lateral cerebellum is responsible for peripheral coordination.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset neck pain, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty walking for the past hour. She cannot sit upright without propping herself up on her hands. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation. She does not smoke. She drinks a glass of wine every other evening. Current medications include enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and warfarin. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 205/148 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows downbeat nystagmus, neck stiffness, head bobbing, and a broad-based gait. She is unable to perform a balance test or Romberg test. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an injury to which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The posterior spinal cord carries the dorsal column, which is responsible for proprioception and sensation of pressure, vibration, and fine touch. Injury to the posterior spinal cord can, therefore, cause sensory ataxia that is worse in dimly lit settings, where a patient's proprioception cannot compensate for the loss of visual bearings. However, this patient's broad-based gait and inability to perform a Romberg test are not environment-dependent. In addition, there is no indication that she has other sensory deficits. Moreover, posterior spinal cord injury is not associated with nystagmus, head bobbing, or truncal ataxia (e.g., inability to sit upright without propping oneself up on the hands).

B) INCORRECT:

The pyramidal tracts control voluntary muscular movement to the face via the corticobulbar tract and to the body via the corticospinal tract. Injury to the corticobulbar tract typically results in manifestations of pseudobulbar palsy (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia, lack of facial expression). Injury to the corticospinal tract classically manifests with upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spasticity, hypertonia, hyperreflexia, clonus, Babinski sign) on the contralateral side. This patient's neurologic examination is not consistent with injury to either pyramidal tract.
Image Description:

Fibers of the pyramidal tract originate from the primary motor cortex and descend to the brain stem via the internal capsule. Bulbar corticonuclear fibers extend to each of the cranial nerve nuclei, which innervate the facial muscles. The remaining fibers descend from the brainstem as two divisions of the corticospinal tract. Approximately 80% of these fibers decussate at the level of the medulla (pyramidal decussation) to the contralateral side to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They then descend into the spinal cord to innervate the limbs and digits. The remaining approximately 20% of fibers descend from the brainstem ipsilaterally, forming the anterior corticospinal tract. These decussate at the spinal level of the trunk muscles they innervate.

C) CORRECT:

The cerebellar vermis is a midline structure of the cerebellum that is involved in the coordination of the vestibular system, eye movements, balance, and complex and sequential movements. This patient's findings of downbeat nystagmus, head bobbing, and truncal ataxia (evidenced by her inability to sit upright without propping herself up on her hands) indicate that the site of injury is the cerebellar vermis. Lesions of the medial parts of the cerebellum (vermis, flocculonodular lobe, and corresponding deep nuclei) affect medial structures of the body (e.g., axial and proximal limb musculature), resulting in truncal ataxia and nystagmus. Lesions of the lateral parts of cerebellum (hemispheres) affect lateral structures of the body (e.g., distal limb musculature), resulting in ipsilateral limb ataxia.
Image Description:

Dorsocaudal view (without brainstem)

D) INCORRECT:

The flocculonodular lobe is a midline cerebellar structure involved in regulating balance, ocular movements, and gaze stability. Midline cerebellar injury can cause head bobbing, truncal ataxia (e.g., inability to sit upright without propping oneself up on the hands), and nystagmus. However, flocculonodular lobe injury is typically associated with upbeat or rebound nystagmus, not the downbeat nystagmus seen in this patient, and usually manifests with vertigo.

E) INCORRECT:

The frontal lobe is involved in several processes, including motor function, memory, and attention. Injury to the bilateral parts of the frontal lobe can result in a frontal gait, which manifests with a broad-based gait and difficulty with balance. However, a frontal lobe injury also typically causes problems with initiating gait, slow steps, and inappropriate compensatory mechanisms for changes in posture while walking. In addition, frontal lobe injury is also associated with the reemergence of primitive reflexes and deficits in concentration and judgment. Moreover, conditions that cause bilateral frontal lobe injury, such as Alzheimer dementia, frontotemporal dementia, and normal pressure hydrocephalus, commonly manifest in a more chronic to subacute timeframe.

F) INCORRECT:

The right and left cerebellar hemispheres are involved in complex motor functions that involve the limbs. Cerebellar hemisphere injury can cause loss of balance but does not typically result in downbeat nystagmus, head bobbing, or truncal ataxia (e.g., inability to sit upright without propping oneself up on the hands). Moreover, this patient does not have other common manifestations of cerebellar hemisphere injury, including limb ataxia (e.g., dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, intention tremor), which typically affects the ipsilateral side, and dysarthria.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset headache and nonspecific neurologic symptoms (e.g., meningismus, nausea, vomiting) in a hypertensive patient on anticoagulation are highly suspicious for the development of intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl who has been vomiting two to four times daily for the past week is brought in for evaluation. She has not had any fever or diarrhea. She complains of occasional abdominal pain, and her appetite is slightly diminished.
On physical examination, she appears to be well nourished and does not appear dehydrated. She is able to state her name and age, and she knows she is in the doctor’s office. She is afebrile, and her vital signs are normal. Her head-and-neck examination is normal, with full range of motion of her neck. Her pupils are reactive to light, and her face is symmetric. Her chest is clear, and heart is regular with no murmurs. Her abdomen is soft, without guarding or rigidity. When asked to walk to her parents, the girl has a wide-based, unsteady gait and leans to the right.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given that the patient is well hydrated and afebrile, laboratory evaluation for electrolytes is unlikely to be helpful. Such evaluation would be indicated if dehydration or acidosis were suspected.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has been vomiting, she is afebrile, and her abdominal examination is normal. It is therefore unlikely that an intra-abdominal process is causing her symptoms. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis is not warranted.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is much more sensitive than CT for cerebellar masses and other causes of ataxia, such as encephalomyelitis, and is therefore the preferred imaging test in this scenario.

D) CORRECT:

Ataxia, a movement disorder characterized by abnormal coordination, often manifests in children as a wide-based, unsteady gait. To distinguish among the various possible causes of ataxia — benign, self-limiting conditions (e.g., acute cerebellar ataxia or acute disseminated encephalomyelitis); infectious diseases (e.g., encephalitis); and malignancies (e.g., brain tumor) — the provider should elicit a history of headaches, fever, systemic symptoms, changes in mental status, and neurologic symptoms. More-focal symptoms are of particular note. The provider should pay special attention to the neurologic and cerebellar examinations, although those may be difficult to conduct in a young child. Any red flags in the history or examination (e.g., nighttime or early morning headaches, vomiting, altered mental status, focal neurologic findings) merit further evaluation with brain imaging.

In this patient, the combination of vomiting and ataxia suggests a brain lesion, such as a tumor, and neuroimaging is indicated. MRI is much more sensitive than CT for cerebellar masses and other causes of ataxia, such as encephalomyelitis, and is therefore the preferred imaging test in this scenario.

Key learning point: The most critical initial step in evaluating an afebrile well-hydrated child with acute ataxia and recent-onset vomiting is MRI of the brain.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's history and examination do not suggest an infectious cause of ataxia. Although lumbar puncture may be warranted in evaluating some causes of ataxia, imaging should be performed before lumbar puncture when there is concern about a possible intracranial mass, as in this child.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, she underwent surgical resection and chemotherapy for adenocarcinoma of the lung. Since her last office visit, her speech has changed. She now makes awkward pauses in her sentences and breaks down words into separate syllables. On physical examination, her movements are uncoordinated and she leans to the right side when standing up. A CT scan of the brain shows a well-circumscribed tumor in her right cerebellar hemisphere. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Upbeat nystagmus is a form of involuntary, rhythmic eye movement. It is associated with lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, one of the medial structures of the cerebellum. Other manifestations of medial cerebellum injury include head bobbing, wide-based gait, and inability to stand or sit upright. A lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere most commonly manifests with horizontal nystagmus, not upbeat nystagmus.

B) CORRECT:

The finger-to-nose test assesses for appendicular coordination; an abnormal result (i.e., the patient overshoots the target or misses the tip of their nose) indicates dysmetria. Dysmetria is one of several manifestations of limb ataxia due to cerebellar hemisphere injury. Other manifestations include dysarthria (which this patient has), dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, and intention tremor. Typically, the lesions affect the ipsilateral side, which explains why this patient leans toward the right side upon standing.

C) INCORRECT:

Truncal ataxia manifests with a wide-based gait and difficulty sitting upright due to weakness and discoordination of truncal muscles. Truncal ataxia is associated with lesions in the medial cerebellum (e.g., vermis, flocculonodular lobe, and corresponding deep nuclei). This patient's limb ataxia and right hemisphere metastasis are evidence of a lateral lesion, which would not manifest with truncal ataxia.

D) INCORRECT:

Resting tremors manifest when the affected body part is relaxed and resolve with voluntary movement. This condition is commonly associated with Parkinson disease, which is caused by dysfunction of the substantia nigra in the basal ganglia. Cerebellar hemisphere lesions are associated with intention tremors (worsen with voluntary movements), not resting tremors.

E) INCORRECT:

The Romberg test assesses sensory ataxia. A positive test (patients lose balance while standing upright with their eyes closed) is associated with damage to the dorsal columns of the spine. It is not associated with damage to the lateral cerebellar hemisphere.
questions.hint: The medial cerebellum primarily manages the coordination of central structures. The lateral cerebellum is responsible for peripheral coordination.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up. Six months ago, she had surgical resection and chemotherapy for lung adenocarcinoma. Since her last visit, her speech has changed; she now makes awkward pauses in her sentences and breaks down words into separate syllables. On examination, her movements are uncoordinated and she leans to the right when standing. A CT scan of the brain shows a well-circumscribed tumor in the right cerebellar hemisphere. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Truncal ataxia manifests with a wide-based gait and difficulty sitting upright due to weakness and discoordination of truncal muscles. Truncal ataxia is associated with lesions in the medial cerebellum (e.g., vermis, flocculonodular lobe, and corresponding deep nuclei). This patient's limb ataxia and right hemisphere metastasis are evidence of a lateral lesion, which would not manifest with truncal ataxia.

B) INCORRECT:

The Romberg test assesses sensory ataxia. A positive test (patients lose balance while standing upright with their eyes closed) is associated with damage to the dorsal columns of the spine. It is not associated with damage to the lateral cerebellar hemisphere.

C) INCORRECT:

Upbeat nystagmus is a form of involuntary, rhythmic eye movement. It is associated with lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, one of the medial structures of the cerebellum. Other manifestations of medial cerebellum injury include head bobbing, wide-based gait, and inability to stand or sit upright. A lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere most commonly manifests with horizontal nystagmus, not upbeat nystagmus.

D) INCORRECT:

Resting tremors manifest when the affected body part is relaxed and resolve with voluntary movement. This condition is commonly associated with Parkinson disease, which is caused by dysfunction of the substantia nigra in the basal ganglia. Cerebellar hemisphere lesions are associated with intention tremors (worsen with voluntary movements), not resting tremors.

E) CORRECT:

The finger-to-nose test assesses for appendicular coordination; an abnormal result (i.e., the patient overshoots the target or misses the tip of their nose) indicates dysmetria. Dysmetria is one of several manifestations of limb ataxia due to cerebellar hemisphere injury. Other manifestations include dysarthria (which this patient has), dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, and intention tremor. Typically, the lesions affect the ipsilateral side, which explains why this patient leans toward the right side upon standing.

Key learning point: Cerebellar hemisphere lesions cause ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, and abnormal finger-to-nose testing, but do not produce truncal ataxia or a positive Romberg sign.
questions.hint: The medial cerebellum primarily manages the coordination of central structures. The lateral cerebellum is responsible for peripheral coordination.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after falling from a ladder and hitting the back of his head on concrete. He was briefly unconscious, but is now alert and answers questions appropriately. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He works as a house painter. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances. On arrival, he is awake and oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 136/80 mm Hg. The patient is unable to place one foot directly in front of the other when asked to walk in a straight line. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus with fast beats toward the right. Right-sided finger-to-nose test shows dysmetria and tremor. Muscle strength and sensation are normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an injury to which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The thalamus acts as a relay center for sensory signals and some motor signals to the cerebral cortex. A lesion in the left thalamus typically manifests with right-sided weakness and sensory loss, and it does not cause ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, or nystagmus.

B) INCORRECT:

The pons contains numerous ascending and descending tracts. A pontine lesion could cause ataxia by damaging the cerebellar peduncles. However, this patient does not have other typical signs of a pontine lesion, such as contralateral weakness (from corticospinal tract damage) and cranial nerve palsies (e.g., CN VI or VII). Isolated right-sided limb ataxia makes a pontine lesion unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

The cerebellar vermis is responsible for coordinating axial and proximal trunk muscles, playing a key role in gait and balance. Lesions of the vermis typically cause truncal ataxia and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Vermis lesions are unlikely to cause limb ataxia or lateralized nystagmus.

D) INCORRECT:

The frontal lobe is involved in executive function, personality, voluntary movement (via the primary motor cortex), and speech (Broca area). Lesions in this region may lead to contralateral weakness, behavioral changes, or motor aphasia. Ipsilateral limb ataxia and nystagmus make a frontal lobe lesion unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

The cerebellum modulates and coordinates voluntary limb movements, with each cerebellar hemisphere controlling the ipsilateral side of the body. This patient’s right-sided limb ataxia (finger-to-nose dysmetria and intention tremor) indicates right cerebellar hemisphere injury. The right-beating horizontal nystagmus further supports the diagnosis of a lesion on the right side. Other common manifestations of cerebellar hemisphere injury include gait ataxia, dysdiadochokinesia, hypotonia, and dysarthria. Cerebellar injury does not cause weakness or sensory loss.
questions.hint: This patient likely has a positive heel-knee-shin test on the right side.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to a 2-day history of an unsteady gait. His mother reports that he recovered from a widespread, itchy, vesicular rash two weeks ago. He is afebrile and alert. On examination, he has a wide-based gait and significant truncal instability when attempting to sit unsupported. Sensation to pinprick and touch is intact. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for acute postviral cerebellitis. It is an immune-mediated process that typically occurs 1–3 weeks after a viral infection, most commonly varicella. The condition is typically self-limiting, with most children recovering fully within a few weeks. The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating balance, gait, and eye movements. Therefore, in addition to truncal ataxia and a wide-based gait, other cerebellar signs are common. Nystagmus, an involuntary rhythmic oscillation of the eyes, is frequently observed due to the cerebellum's role in coordinating ocular motor control.

B) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity areflexia is seen in patients with lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions, which can cause gait instability. However, patients with LMN lesions typically present with a steppage gait rather than a broad-based gait. In addition, hypotonia and decreased muscle strength would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

An extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign) is a possible finding in patients with upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions, which can cause gait instability. However, patients with UMN lesions typically present with hypertonia, hyperreflexia, and decreased muscle strength.

D) INCORRECT:

A positive Kernig sign indicates meningeal irritation, which is a key finding in meningitis. While meningitis can be a post-infectious complication and cause neurologic symptoms, this patient is afebrile and alert. The clinical picture of isolated ataxia without fever, headache, or neck stiffness makes meningitis less likely.
questions.hint: This child's acute onset of truncal ataxia and wide-based gait following a recent viral illness is characteristic of a post-infectious inflammatory process affecting the cerebellum.
